Interview with Harry Bass
April 21, 1992
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

segments.question: My name is Anthony Dilorio and I am here to interview Mr. Harry Bass about the experiences of his family during the Holocaust.
segments.answer: Good evening.

segments.question: What was your name when you were born in Poland?
segments.answer: Herszel.

segments.question: And when were you born?
And where were you born?
segments.answer: Bialystok, Poland.

segments.question: What kind of family did you have?
segments.answer: There were six kids and my parents. Eight people in our family. We had some distant relatives, cousins and uncles.

segments.question: What kind of house did you live in?
segments.answer: Single family home.

segments.question: A single family home?
segments.answer: I remember that.

segments.question: Did you have a garden?
segments.answer: No, no garden.

segments.question: So you lived right in the city?
segments.answer: A short little distance, but it was considered the city.

segments.question: What languages were spoken in your home? 1
segments.answer: Yiddish.

segments.question: Did you and your family speak other languages outside your home?
segments.answer: I speak Polish, I speak Russian, I speak German a little bit.

segments.question: What did your father do for a living?
segments.answer: We were always in the meat business.

segments.question: So was he a retailor?
segments.answer: Retailer.

segments.question: He had a butcher shop?
segments.answer: Yeah, three of them.

segments.question: Three butcher shops in Bialystok? What kind of schooling did you have?
segments.answer: I graduate, I finished high school.

segments.question: In Bialystok?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And what did you study? What were you going to be?
segments.answer: I wouldn’t know exactly, I wouldn’t make predictions now. But that period was the best times, the best years of my life. I was 19 or 20 years of age.

segments.question: Did you have plans to be anything in particular?
segments.answer: Absolutely. My parents didn’t want me to be in the same profession.

segments.question: Did they have anything in particular in mind for you?
segments.answer: Nothing in particular, as far as I know. They never talked about it.

segments.question: Was your mother a housewife?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Where did she come from? 2
segments.answer: She was born in a little town not far from Bialystok. The name of the town was Kosoff.

segments.question: Do you know how many brothers and sisters she had?
segments.answer: They were a family of nine people. I mean nine kids.

segments.question: Nine kids. She was one of nine kids.
segments.answer: She was the youngest of nine.

segments.question: What did she do before she married your father? Did she have a job?
segments.answer: She never had a job.

segments.question: Did she grow up in Kosoff?
segments.answer: She grow up until she got married. Then she moved to Bialystok.

segments.question: Your father, what did he do at that time?
segments.answer: My father was in Polish army.

segments.question: Polish army?
segments.answer: Until the First World War.

data: He settled down. He got into the same line my grandfather was also in the meat business. My father wasn’t because he was young and he was taken in the army. When he came out he was married so he helped out his father-in-law, my grandfather. That’s how he got in his own business.

segments.question: And then he went on to have three stores?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Did you get involved?
segments.answer: Oh yes, I was a big help and my other brother I showed you in the picture, Boruch.

segments.question: Your brother, Boruch. When was he born?
segments.answer: He was born a couple of years after I am. 3

data: What kind of schooling did he have? The same as you?

Most of the time it was public school. You see a public school in Poland was a little advanced, better rated than the United States public school. So if you graduated at 14 or 15 years of age, it’s almost like a high school. Them years we didn’t have universities like we have . We had gymnasium, something like between public school and college.

segments.question: Did any of you go to the gymnasium?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No. So you and your brothers completed grade school and then high school?
segments.answer: Then we helped out our family.

segments.question: In meat stores? Did anyone in your family play musical instruments?
segments.answer: I played.

segments.question: You played?
segments.answer: I played the accordion.

segments.question: You played the accordion? You liked to play at home or did you play outside the home?
segments.answer: I used to play mostly at home for our own entertainment. I used to play outside -- not professionally.

segments.question: Did you participate in any sports?
segments.answer: Yes, running.

segments.question: You were a runner?
segments.answer: I was in second place too, in 1939.

segments.question: Oh. In 1939?
segments.answer: Yes, the Russians. See the Russians occupied our town.

segments.question: Yes, in the fall of 1939. 4
segments.answer: Sure, so the Russians came in and to them sport was a big deal. Everybody had to be involved. They let you off from work and I used to run seven or eight kilometers. I used to do ,

segments.question: Did you run before the Russians came in?
segments.answer: No. I used to ride bicycles.

segments.question: So you were a bicyclist?
segments.answer: You saw it.

segments.question: That was you on the bike?
segments.answer: Right. It still has my name on it.

segments.question: And that was bought when? When did your parents give you that bicycle?
segments.answer: My Bar Mitzvah.

segments.question: Bar Mitzvah?
segments.answer: I hope I didn’t forget my pictures over there.

segments.question: No, they’re on the table. Any other sports? Bicycling and Running?
segments.answer: Dancing.

segments.question: Dancing? Did you have girl friends?
segments.answer: Oh yeah, oh yeah, oh yeah. They were fighting over who would do the dancing with me.

segments.question: They were fighting over you?
segments.answer: Who was going to do the dancing with me. My wife knowed that because sometime we get together with friends we grew up together. There was one guy we grew up together, same age. His family had a bakery shop next to ours, we had the butcher shop, so . And luckily, I had a pretty good memory. Some guys sometimes .

segments.question: Did you have a fiancee?
segments.answer: A girlfriend? I sure did. 5

segments.question: Just one girlfriend?
segments.answer: Just one girlfriend.

segments.question: But you weren’t engaged to be married?
segments.answer: No. she never made it.

segments.question: How about your brother Boruch?
segments.answer: He had a girlfriend too. Her brother survived. I remember she had the same name as my mother, Chaje. She didn’t survive, her brother survived because he was in the Russian army. When the Russians occupied Bialystok they took the young guys, like 17, 18 years of age, they took them into the Russian service, 19, 20’s they sent us to school. We used to call it military preparation. Teaching how to maneuver (?). If 1t would be another year, they would probably take us into the army too.

segments.question: Your brother Boruch, what sort of sports was he active in? He looked like he was the athletic type.
segments.answer: None.

segments.question: Did he play any musical instruments?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: What do you think of most when you think of him as a young boy?
segments.answer: Young boy?

segments.question: Yeah. Did he have any career plans?
segments.answer: He was like the other boys. I don’t think so. The young sometimes you don’t think those things. Especially when you are young you were so tight in the family. We lived like the other young boys, wild.

segments.question: Wild?
segments.answer: Sometimes you do things then you realize you made a mistake. I don’t have to tell you -- you know.

segments.question: Were your parents strict?
segments.answer: Oh yeah. My father didn’t have to do nothing -- just look at us. 6

segments.question: And your mother?
segments.answer: My mother, no she was a softie.

segments.question: A softie?
segments.answer: We used to take advantage of her sometimes. One thing, my mother, when it came to her daughter, you couldn’t say anything to her, you couldn’t touch her, my sister. Only one, she said, only one daughter.

segments.question: Was she the youngest child?
segments.answer: No, she’s between the two younger ones.

segments.question: She’s the middle.
segments.answer: She’s the smallest. Of course I have another brother who lives in Florida. I told you, he’s the one, he’s next to Boruch and older than my sister.

segments.question: Did you mother have any hobbies at home? I know she was a very busy woman with all those kids. Did she sing or play the piano?
segments.answer: No. She used to make knitting.

segments.question: Crocheting?
segments.answer: Makes people or animals.

segments.question: Paper Mache?
segments.answer: Hand knitting.

segments.question: Needlepoint?
segments.answer: Needlepoint. Oh yeah, she used to make all kinds of animals and sceneries and all that. She liked to make animals and sceneries and all that. . We survived because of this. They used to come down and ask him to take pictures

data: What can you tell us about your youngest brothers, Izrael and Iszmuel?
They were little boys. They were still in school. (very difficult to hear) August 16, 1943 it was the liquidation of the ghetto.
August 16, 1943, they liquidated Bialystok ghetto. (Very difficult to hear.

segments.question: So your mother and your three brothers?
segments.answer: Two.

segments.question: Your two younger brothers.
segments.answer: The second one to me, couldn’t come out of the ghetto . (Very difficult to hear)

segments.question: Do you know when that was?
And you mentioned that under the Russians there was interest in sports?
segments.answer: Oh yeah. The youngsters participated.

segments.question: Were there any other changes under the Russians?
segments.answer: A lot of changes.

segments.question: Was it better or worse?
segments.answer: I would say better. The problem of the last years of 1938-39 you see Poland had a history of it’s own. The President passed away, Pilsudski, I don’t know if you heard of him.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: When he passed away we used to call him the Jewish grandfather. He was saved by a Jewish guy. How he was saved, he broke up that time with Stalin and Lenin. They were all together when they started out the Revolution. He was a Socialist when they broke up. He start running away. When he came into a village and that particular village was a blacksmith and he run into the blacksmith and put him down the arm against the wall with Jewish religious things on him and the Cossacks chasing were chasing him, they came in, they looked for him and they couldn’t find him. They saw him and when they came out back so the officer said to him did you see him. He said no, there’s an old man, an old Jew with his pals and his tzitses (spelling). And he survived.

segments.question: Now he became a Jewish grandfather? 8
segments.answer: That’s it. And he was there. As soon as he passed away --

segments.question: What happened?
segments.answer: Anti-Semitism. They used to have boycotts. It’s a privilege to boycott

segments.question: So even in Bialystok you had boycotts?
segments.answer: Oh yeah.

segments.question: How about your father’s meat stores?
segments.answer: Oh yeah. Meat is another story to talk about. We used to kill kosher meat . They passed a law that they wanted to take away from people Jewish kosher killed. The whole world protested at that time, 1937, 38. So finally they permitted to kill kosher so much and so much. I will never forget as long as I live, we used to sell a lot of restaurants in Bialystok. So one morning I came in like 5:00, 6:00 in the morning . The main meal is lunchtime, so they stopped cooking about 7:00, 8:00 in the morning, so I had to be in the store 5:00, 6 o’clock in the morning. We had one store wasn’t too far from the railroad station so at 5 o’clock when the shift changes in the railroad workers so they banged on the door. Mr. Bass, Mr. Bass, grandfather died. That’s how we heard the news that the grandfather passed away.

segments.question: Grandfather Pilsudski? Besides the boycott and the limit on kosher killing of animals for meat, were there other changes after he died?
segments.answer: Well, I wouldn’t say I exactly remember. Like I said before, you’re young and you don’t realize those Naturally there were a lot of changes . (The tape is difficult to hear). The Germans had a lot of influence at that time. In our hometown lived a lot of Germans. They remained from the First World War. They were manufacturing textiles. Bialystok is the second largest city in Europe in textiles.

segments.question: You described the German population of Bialystok. When it came to anti- Semitism who was the greatest danger to you, the Germans of Bialystok or the Poles?
segments.answer: The Germans maybe they did it more in intelligence, but the Poles did it like pogroms or fighting or things like that.

segments.question: So there were pogroms in Bialystok? 9
segments.answer: Not in Bialystok direct because Bialystok was 85 to 90 percent Jewish city. So they didn’t start it up. Bur there were some other cities

segments.question: Who controlled Bialystok? With the large Jewish population, who controlled the city government?
segments.answer: Polacks. Jewish hardly were elected. Doctors, lawyers, yes.

segments.question: When the Russians came in was your father able to keep his stores?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: He was in the army, wasn’t he?
segments.answer: No, he was 39 he wasn’t in the army.

segments.question: But they took him away? Why did they take him away’?
segments.answer: Three stores.

segments.question: Three stores -- bourgeois. And they sent him where?
segments.answer: My father was liberated, he was innocent. When he came in, the same day he came in when my father was arrested, we came into the police station and started asking for my father. So they told us to see one of the big jails there. We used to cut our bread in half and send the other half to my father. After the liberation in 45-46, my father and I got together, my father and I lived together. We slept in one bed and we cried our tears out. He told me he has never seen Brisk (?), he never even knew how it looked. They put him in . They sent him six weeks -- sixty days and sixty nights.

segments.question: Siberia?
segments.answer: Six weeks, they took him that long. He always used to kid me. If you would be there we used to cut trees, he used to tell me a dozen people could dance a waltz on it such huge trees.

segments.question: Did your family get any word from him during that time?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No one knew what happened to him, no letters, nothing?
segments.answer: Nothing. We didn’t expect that. But right when the war ended, he used to write letters. In Bialystok, we used to have a guy used to take care of our accounts. He was an accountant, so my father used to send a letter to him and we used to send 10 letters from Germany because we were liberated from Germany. Somehow my sister was liberated not far from Poland and we spoke to each other said we going to be liberated we’ll all come back to Bialystok. But who knew the circumstances with Germany and Russia with borders and all that, but she made it into Poland. Came to my home town there were maybe ten, twelve people, they all left they couldn’t stay there . That’s how we got together with my father we brought him into Bialystok then to Germany and then to the United States.

segments.question: You were in Bialystok in September 1939, when the war broke out? What were you doing?
segments.answer: My father was there. What was I doing? I was working in the kitchen.

segments.question: Did the Germans come?
segments.answer: The Germans came two years later, 1941. Because Poland, if you look at a map, you see Poland has a river the Bug.

segments.question: And the Russians took the East and the Germans took the West. So for a year and a half almost two years, you are under the Russians. So what did you and the family do?
segments.answer: They sent us to school.

segments.question: They sent you to school?
segments.answer: Their school. They allowed us. After 4 o’clock they sent us to Russian school. I just tried to explain the reason why, they prepared us for the army. A year later or two years later they would probably take us into the service.

segments.question: How did your family make ends meet? Your father was gone, the meat stores were gone?
segments.answer: It’s a good question.

segments.question: It’s a good question, it had to have been tough. Your mother had all these kids.
segments.answer: Yeah. I’m trying to tell you a story, you wouldn’t believe it.

segments.question: You worked in ....?
segments.answer: I just mentioned a minute ago that there were textile factories and I worked in the textiles. When the Russians came in they used to take like three or four places, they call it and guard them together. 11

segments.question: Cooperative?
segments.answer: Cooperative. They called them . And they made a kitchen there. The textiles run three shifts every day, day and night. We had to prepare twenty-four meals a day for three shifts. One time, they always used to have a lot of dancing, the Russians. In that same factory they built up a place with a platform, they used to go every night dancing. I was a youngster, I was dressed nicely and the director was a Russian guy. He used to come over all the time and ask “where did you get it?” I said, what do you mean where did we get it? We bought it. I was young, I didn’t know what to answer. I didn’t know their system in Russian. He said, you mean you have money, you go to the store you bought shoes, you bought a suit. One time coming there in October I meet this one, this one and this one. . Ineed sugar. Where am I going to get sugar. Tovarich, you know what Tovarich 1s?

segments.question: Comrade.
segments.answer: Comrade, director, where am I going to get sugar for you? He said how many pounds of sugar do you put in each shift? Three tanks, each shift we used to put in a tank of coffee. Each shift is a tank of coffee and we used to put in sugar and coffee together. We used to put in five kilo? Because there was 1,800 cups. I'll tell you what to do, put in four kilo from now on. I never know from those things, how could I steal a pound of sugar from it. I gave it to him. But then he opened the door for me. ;

segments.question: So then you had help? This job you got when the Russians came in, this was after the Russians came in, the job in the kitchen. This was after the Russians came in?
segments.answer: In 1939. The end of ’39.

segments.question: And you worked in this kitchen?
segments.answer: I managed it. Because I can explain it. I was a very good comedian. Today I happen to be a good cook. . When we supplied the restaurants I used to pick up the orders and get on my bicycle when it wasn’t too busy.

segments.question: When you were working for your father?
segments.answer: Yeah, I would get on my bicycle, it was a distance. If 1t wasn’t too much. Otherwise I had to take the bus. That’s how I knew about cooking, I used to come around, sometimes the Polacks they used to stay in the kitchen they used to call me over and show me how to do this and how to do this. . So this way that’s how I made sure my family had food.

segments.question: The job in the kitchen, how long did you work there? 12
segments.answer: Maybe a year and a half.

segments.question: Until the Germans came?
segments.answer: Until the Germans came. At that time they all escaped. We came back that was on Saturday night, I'll never forget. We came back from a dance Saturday night, it must have been two or three o’clock in the morning. Two, three o’clock summertime, the sun is already out in June. So I go home and I see all the Soviets barefooted, one shoe on, one shoe off. They are running like crazy, like I kept asking what’s happening? They said the Germans are back. They were at that time also drunk and they came from dancing places or entertainment places and they came after midnight and they came to the barracks. Where we used to live near the army barracks.

segments.question: So the Russian army barracks were near your home?
segments.answer: Not too far, maybe a couple of miles, a couple of kilometers. That’s how we had enough food.

segments.question: Your mother cooked it all?
segments.answer: I was always a good supplier. Even when I worked in the concentration camp, what do you think, how do I survive. I was three and one half years in Auschwitz. How many survived? I also worked in the kitchen. When we came up in the transport at Auschwitz so they started announcing they needed “mescher” (spelling) So you know what a “mescher’”’ is?

segments.question: Yes, a butcher.
segments.answer: That’s it. A “mescher” so everybody is raising their hands. Give them a knife and a skin and check out how he cuts it. So help me God when I came over as soon as I took the skin and the knife, he said “du bist gut.”

segments.question: Let’s back up just a little bit, when the Germans came in in June 1941, after the dance, you came home and the Germans are coming in what happens in Bialystok? How did things change? Do you lose your job?
segments.answer: You mean when the Germans came in?

segments.question: Yes, when the Germans come in in 1941, what happens?
segments.answer: First of all as soon as they came in they start grabbing Jews and throwing them into the synagogues and burning up.

segments.question: Immediately? 13
segments.answer: Immediately. Shooting and killing. People were afraid to go out they didn’t know what was going on because some of the Jewish people from Warsaw, from Waltz? They crossed they already told us the horror. And some of them tried to skip out and go into Russia, and some of them survived this way.

segments.question: So you weren’t surprised that the Germans were killing people?
segments.answer: No we were not. You couldn’t imagine that people would kill people. You couldn’t imagine that kind of horror.

segments.question: You knew who Hitler was then?
segments.answer: Sure, we used to hear him talking. He used to come on the radio, he was like a dog you couldn’t stop him. He would go three hours.

segments.question: So when the Germans come in they grabbed and they killed Jews. What else did they do?
segments.answer: What else did they do? One Saturday, they took over two thousand Jews and put them in the main synagogue and put some fire bombs in and the city was burning for three days and three nights. The whole city

segments.question: No one in your family, though?
segments.answer: We lived a little bit out of the center.

segments.question: What else happened under the Germans? Was there a ghetto?
segments.answer: Oh yes. Then they came after a few days and gave everybody a star. Then they formed the ghetto. My father remained home, we were not bombed out.

segments.question: Did you have to move?
segments.answer: Oh yeah.

segments.question: So your mother and everybody .....
segments.answer: Our house was not in the ghetto section, our house. Our house had no choice to save their . But we had to move. Every little thing in life is lucky. That guy I mentioned before used to take care on feeding the animals, the cows and the pigs, we used to call him not exactly a maintenance man. He used to take down all the things from the stables, feeding the cows, milking the cows. His house wasn’t far from the ghetto.

segments.question: The whole family stayed together? What did your mother take? 14
segments.answer: Soft things. We schlepped.

segments.question: I mean, how much time did you have to prepare for this move?
segments.answer: They gave us, I don’t know exactly, but they gave a short time, maybe a day or two. We were young guys. We made a big pack and we were walking with it. Whatever we could take we schlepped. We couldn’t take too much because this house we lived in in the ghetto, they organized the Jewish Judenrat. Judenrat means a house. So many narrows (?) per person. That house, what do you think they did, they took in my brother’s girlfriend’s family, my girlfriend’s parents, we were three families.

segments.question: Quite a crowd. Three families in one apartment. Any other changes under the Germans? Did you have any job?
segments.answer: No. They used to take us out . After awhile the ghetto got so filled up it wasn’t enough room for the people. So they came to the conclusion they’re going to evacuate some of the people from the ghetto to a little town called Pruzany not far from Greece. So they first came out that the Judenrat they go by the ABC. The second day was our next. So they loaded us up on trucks to take us to Pruzany. We had to go through a control, a German control very difficult to hear.

segments.question: So your family moved to Pruzany? Do you remember when?
segments.answer: No. . We were there a little while after Bialystok. From Pruzany, then they took us out.

segments.question: So you had to move twice. You had to move into the ghetto, and how long were you in the ghetto?
segments.answer: Close to a year, less than a year. We got into the ghetto in eight or nine months.

segments.question: Then the following summer you had to go to Pruzany?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And how long were you in Pruzany?
segments.answer: Until January 1943.

segments.question: And the family 1s still together?
segments.answer: No. Just myself, my sister and my two younger brothers. 15

segments.question: Your two youngest brothers and your mother? Now when you were in the ghetto and you had to do clean up work for the Germans, did Boruch have to do that too?
segments.answer: Oh yes,

segments.question: Do you remember when that happened?
segments.answer: That happened during the winter months. I don’t know exactly, I know it was cold weather. In the summertime you couldn’t face the night because you are lightly dressed so you can notice it. Wintertime you had a better chance, you had a heavier coat, heavier pair of pants, whatever. You had a better chance

segments.question: How about your youngest brothers, did they have to do any work for the Germans?
segments.answer: They used to take them out for chopping wood, sweeping out .

segments.question: How about Izrael? He had to work in Pruzany? But not Iszmuel? How about your mother? Did they leave her alone?
In Pruzany you were working?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: What did you have to do there?
segments.answer: The same garbage. Cutting wood, it was wintertime, they needed wood to heat their houses. Everything, whatever they told me to do. If it was snowing I had to clean up the snow around.

segments.question: And your sister and Izrael had to do work too?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And how did your family get enough food to eat in Pruzany?
segments.answer: There was rations. If you go outside you had a chance sometimes you could find something valuable. You could change for something. .

segments.question: And you were able to smuggle some food in? 16
segments.answer: Oh yes. Believe me the Germans, some of them were a little bit more liberal, they wouldn’t raise their head, they didn’t want to look at you. Some of them used to smuggle in. I used to smuggle in a lot of food from the Germans. In the wintertime while they slept . It was nice and quiet I used to go out and take out some valuables and change it . We used to make like double bags and schlep cornmeal, beans, anything edible. Whatever came along. Corn flour we used to bake bread ;

segments.question: Now you’re in Pruzany between August 1942 and January 1943. What happened in January?
segments.answer: It was liquidation of the ghetto.

segments.question: Liquidation of Pruzany?
segments.answer: We went to Auschwitz.

segments.question: Do you remember when that was?
segments.answer: This much I can tell you From Pruzany we had to go to a train station called Linowa.

segments.question: So there was no train station in Pruzany?
segments.answer: No. The train station was a little small town about eight kilometers outside of the old walk (?) . And finally they loaded us up on the train and the train started to move already. I wanted to jump. I couldn’t do it. (Very sad, tears).

data: You couldn’t jump? (reverse side) SIDE B

segments.question: And you were all together in the railroad car? This was a cattle car.
segments.answer: Cattle car. Some people jumped .

segments.question: What did your mother say? She was the head of the family? What was she saying?
segments.answer: Well, the same thing.

segments.question: Stay together? 17
segments.answer: My mother stayed together when they took us off the train, in Auschwitz. She thought maybe we would survive .

segments.question: The train left mid January and you traveled straight to Auschwitz. How many days did it take?
segments.answer: Three days.

segments.question: Did your family have any food?
segments.answer: Nothing.

segments.question: Nothing to eat?
segments.answer: No. Whatever we took we had ;

segments.question: What were people doing and saying when they were in the train for three days? It was cold, I imagine.
segments.answer: It was cold, people were afraid, all kinds of people were thinking all kinds of things. . People were praying.

segments.question: When you arrived, your family is split?
segments.answer: Right ,

data: So you’re separated from your brothers?
